video.title: NestJs Course for Beginners - Create a REST API
video.description:
Learn NestJs by building a CRUD REST API with end-to-end tests using modern web development techniques. NestJs is a rapidly growing node js framework that helps build scalable and maintainable backend applications.

In this course, we build a bookmarks API from scratch using nestJs, docker, postgres, passport js, prisma, pactum and dotenv.

💻 Code: https://github.com/vladwulf/nestjs-api-tutorial

✏️ Course from Vladimir Agaev. Check out his YouTube channel: https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCjmouj0JizYt0qTI53TAtFg

⭐️ Course Contents ⭐
⌨️ (0:00:00) Course introduction
⌨️ (0:01:15) What is NestJs
⌨️ (0:02:35) Why using NestJs
⌨️ (0:03:35) What we are building
⌨️ (0:03:55) NestJs project setup
⌨️ (0:05:55) Modules
⌨️ (0:15:30) Auth module
⌨️ (0:19:50) Dependency injection
⌨️ (0:20:30) Auth controller
⌨️ (0:26:50) Setting up postgres in docker
⌨️ (0:29:10) Setting up prisma
⌨️ (0:32:10) User & bookmark models
⌨️ (0:35:50) Running prisma migrations
⌨️ (0:40:10) Prisma module
⌨️ (0:52:10) Using auth dtos
⌨️ (0:57:45) NestJs pipes
⌨️ (0:59:10) NestJs global pipe
⌨️ (1:02:50) Hashing user password with argon
⌨️ (1:03:20) Sign up logic
⌨️ (1:13:13) Sign in logic
⌨️ (1:16:50) Automate postgres restart & prisma migrations
⌨️ (1:27:40) NestJs config module
⌨️ (1:34:40) Using passport js & jwt module with nestJs
⌨️ (1:55:10) Get current user with access token
⌨️ (1:57:00) NestJs Guards
⌨️ (2:12:10) NestJs custom param decorator
⌨️ (2:27:10) e2e tests with pactumJs
⌨️ (2:35:10) Setting up test database
⌨️ (2:36:10) Automate test database restart & migrations
⌨️ (2:37:10) Using dotenv cli with prisma
⌨️ (2:44:30) Prisma database teardown logic
⌨️ (2:53:10) Auth e2e tests
⌨️ (3:02:01) User e2e tests
⌨️ (3:13:20) Bookmarks e2e test

🎉 Thanks to our Champion and Sponsor supporters:
👾 Raymond Odero
👾 Agustín Kussrow
👾 aldo ferretti
👾 Otis Morgan
👾 DeezMaster

--

Learn to code for free and get a developer job: https://www.freecodecamp.org

Read hundreds of articles on programming: https://freecodecamp.org/news

topLevelComment.author: Эндуро Крым
topLevelComment.text:
Isn't it better to have data layer separated from business logic? I see you defined Prisma module as global and then used it in every other one, but I see few issues here:
1 - What if it's required to change the data access mechanism? All the business logic would be ruined. Of course it is more handy to use ORMs and do not cover them behind some DAO interface, but but but
2 - Complex work with database can be dirty and all that dirt comes directly to service layer, which I found... you know, dirty)

How am I supposed to do that NestJs way?
I mean I surely can define DAO layer myself in some folder, export singleton objects that will interact with data sources, but I wonder if there's a way to do that inside Nest architecture pattern?

topLevelComment.author: slah Omar
topLevelComment.text: what the name of the terminal used in the course

topLevelComment.author: Aislan de Sousa Maia
topLevelComment.text:
Thanks for the awesome tutorial!!!! Please bring more ^_^ 

But one suggestion: in the tests when you are making use of the "stores" funcionality from "pactum" lib to save variables to use further in next tests... it's not the best approach, because you are creating dependency between the tests when the recommended way is to write tests with scope isolated and independent of each other, so than when one test fails, it will not causing others failing in cascade.

topLevelComment.author: Damin 1
topLevelComment.text:
An unexpected error occurred: "EPERM: operation not permitted, unlink SOLVED!!
You need to run this command: npm cache verify
After that you need to turn off any running server you have, the prisma server and localhost:3333.
This solved it for me I hope I can help someone else.

topLevelComment.author: Jimmy
topLevelComment.text:
At 1:07:05 why do we need to add @@map("users") and @@map("bookmarks")? Vlad goes on to make a comment about "Prisma loves these" but I didn't fully understand what he meant. Any help appreciated.

Awesome tutorial so far with very good explanations.

replies.author: Jimmy
replies.text: It's to adhere to Prisma's naming conventions of using the Singular form, while using a more natural table name (for the context we're dealing with) in the DB.

topLevelComment.author: Yücel Olcay
topLevelComment.text:
I am learning Nest.js currently but I am sorry that I am not satisfied how the concepts are explained for beginners. You dont't give correct and clear information. DI through constructor is not a feature of Nest but typescript. And it's not possible because the argument is preceded only by private. It's possible because private is an access modifier of Typescript and the feature applies to all access modifiers. The way you explain it makes it painful to understand for those who wants to understand the underlying logic. I decided to leave the course at the 20th minute becasue I fear that soon I will face a new concept which I dont know at all and you will just give a superficial explanation.

Edit: Anyway Ive completed the course. Still I think there is a lot to learn from it. Very happy to learn about Prisma and how to use it with Docker. Also its valuable that tests are covered in the course.

Like I expected I faced another vague explanation for setting a @@map for prisma. The explanation was 'Because prisma likes it'. I think its a valuable course but one needs to stop it often and make research if you want to understand the logic behind things.

replies.author: 𝔪𝔟𝔩𝔢
replies.text: @Mofe Nest is for backend api. It is used to build mediator apps for your front end apps (for example written in Next) to communicate with database / make operations on server side

Can you help me differentiate between them? 😂
I already use React with Next

What about Nest ?

replies.author: 𝔪𝔟𝔩𝔢
replies.text: Also Next and Nuxt are easy to remember - nExt: rEact; nUxt: vUe

topLevelComment.author: Michael Stallings
topLevelComment.text:
This is a great video! I have one issue though with the (apparent) way Nest does modules/providers .. If you play the video from about minute 43:40 .. We want to use our Prisma service inside the Auth Service. You see we already have the PrismaService as a provider to the PrismaModule which we import into the AuthModule... However if you pause the video at 44:05 You'll see that in AuthService vsCode's code-completion actually imports the PrismaService directly from prisma/prisma.service.ts .. Yet the way we fix the error is by exporting our PrismaService from the PrismaModule .. Which is honestly just confusing .. If we are going to import and use the PrismaService directly from it's file, then what is the point of using this modular structure? The only way this might be explained is if vsCode is doing the auto-import, but it is not actually being used, that in fact the AuthModule itself is being used to provide the PrismaService to the AuthService at compile/runtime .. 
Hopefully someone else noticed this..

replies.author: Hol Horse
replies.text:
Fixed by changing 'src/prisma/prisma.service' to '../prisma/prisma.service'
Essentially change it from an absolute path to a relative path.
Do this for other 'src/' imports too

replies.author: Abderrahmane Elanizi
replies.text:
Beginners mistake: I wrote a wrong command inside the script :
"db:dev:restart": "npm run db:dev:rm &&  db:dev:up && sleep 1 && prisma:dev:deploy" ,
Where it should be : "db:dev:restart": "npm run db:dev:rm && npm run db:dev:up && sleep 1 && npm run prisma:dev:deploy".

topLevelComment.author: mixxxer
topLevelComment.text: When i run db:dev:restart it empties my DB. I think i understand why, but how do i avoid that for production environments? How does one go about preserving data but still being able to run migrations?

replies.author: Code with Vlad
replies.text: In production you would generate updated migration files with "npx prisma migrate dev --create-only" and apply them to the production database with "npx prisma migrate deploy".

topLevelComment.author: Nijo Joseph
topLevelComment.text:
npx prisma migrate deploy is not always doing npx prisma generate especially after removing container in docker (rm) and bringing up the container. So better do 
"prisma:dev:deploy": "npx prisma generate && npx prisma migrate deploy" 
and 
"prisma:test:deploy": "dotenv -e .env.test -- npx prisma generate && dotenv -e .env.test -- npx prisma migrate deploy" 
in json scripts. 
Also during test direct paths like 
import { GetUser } from 'src/auth/decorator'; 
is not working in windows environment so try
import { GetUser } from '../auth/decorator'; 
relational imports. 
Just advice for beginners from a beginner. Enjoy coding.

replies.author: Code with Vlad
replies.text: It's the only framework that helps to enforce a clean architecture in NodeJs (similar to Spring in Java or ASP.net ). It is popular and used by enterprise. A uk crypto exchange is using it for microservices and they like it.
